questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. His elder brother passed away due to a stroke at the age of 40. The CT abdomen is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The combination of loin pain, hematuria, hypertension, and family history of early stroke strongly indicates autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  • The CT findings of multiple bilateral renal cysts confirm the diagnosis.
  • Stroke in the brother suggests possible intracranial berry aneurysm, a known extrarenal complication of ADPKD.

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD):

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant; mutations in PKD1 (chromosome 16) or PKD2 (chromosome 4).
  • Pathogenesis: Abnormal polycystin protein → cyst formation → renal enlargement and progressive loss of function.
  • Intrarenal features:
    • Hypertension (most common presenting feature).
    • Hematuria, polyuria, nocturia.
    • Loin pain due to hemorrhage, infection, or stones.
    • Progressive renal failure (usually by 5th-6th decade).
  • Extrarenal features:
    • Polycystic liver disease (most common extrarenal).
    • Cysts in pancreas, spleen, ovaries.
    • Berry aneurysms → subarachnoid hemorrhage, stroke.
    • Mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation.
  • Investigations:
    • CECT: investigation of choice.
    • Ultrasound: screening and diagnosis.
    • IVP: shows spider leg deformity, bell-shaped pelvis, "Swiss cheese" appearance.
    • Renal function tests: elevated urea and creatinine.
  • Management:
    • Control hypertension (ACE inhibitors/ARBs).
    • Supportive: treat infections, nephrolithiasis.
    • Drainage or deroofing of symptomatic cysts.
    • Definitive: renal transplantation once end-stage renal disease develops.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Renal cell carcinoma (Option A): Can cause hematuria and loin pain, but typically appears as a solid renal mass rather than multiple bilateral cysts.

Tuberculosis of the kidney (Option C): Causes hematuria, dysuria, and flank pain with sterile pyuria. CT may show calcifications or contracted kidneys ("putty kidney"), not diffuse cysts.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (Option D): Presents in infancy/childhood with hepatic fibrosis and severe renal failure, not in adulthood with preserved renal function until later decades.

Key Takeaway:

ADPKD presents with hypertension, hematuria, loin pain, and a positive family history. CT imaging reveals multiple bilateral cysts, and extrarenal complications (like berry aneurysm leading to stroke) are common. Definitive treatment is renal transplantation.

questions.text: A patient was found to have a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach, which involves the head of the pancreas and metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a gastric tumour extending to the pancreas and showing metastasis to the liver indicates advanced stage gastric carcinoma, which is not resectable with curative intent. In such cases, the priority is palliation to relieve symptoms like gastric outlet obstruction and to improve quality of life. Palliative gastrojejunostomy provides a bypass for gastric contents and reduces obstructive symptoms. This is then followed by systemic chemotherapy, which helps control tumour progression and improve survival.

Treatment of stomach cancer:

  • Surgical treatment (curative): The only definitive option, but requires absence of distant metastasis.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Improves surgical outcomes in resectable disease. The FLOT regimen (fluorouracil, leucovorin, oxaliplatin, docetaxel) has shown superior survival compared to the older ECF regimen (epirubicin, cisplatin, 5-FU).
  • Types of resection:
    • Total gastrectomy: For proximal or diffuse lesions.
    • Subtotal gastrectomy: For distal lesions, with Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Palliative surgery: For inoperable or metastatic cases, gastrojejunostomy is done to relieve obstruction.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Radical gastrectomy (Option B): This would be considered if there was no metastasis, but metastasis to the liver and involvement of the pancreas suggests an advanced stage, making this option less feasible.

Whipple's procedure (Option C): This is a surgery primarily used for pancreatic cancer. Since the present case involves gastric cancer with liver metastasis, this procedure is not appropriate.

Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy (Option D): This could be considered for resectable localized tumours, but in the presence of liver metastasis, it is not an ideal option for curative intent.

Key takeaway: In patients with advanced gastric carcinoma with liver metastasis and local invasion, the management is palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy, not radical curative surgery.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for an elderly male patient who experienced scrotal pain and discharge, as indicated in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with scrotal pain, swelling, and discharge, along with the image showing extensive necrosis, which is highly suggestive of Fournier's gangrene.
  • This is a rapidly progressive necrotizing infection of the perineum, genitalia, and surrounding soft tissues, similar to necrotizing fasciitis.
  • It commonly occurs in immunocompromised states such as diabetes mellitus, alcoholism, malnutrition, and vascular disease.
  • Clinical progression usually follows distinct phases:
    • Prodromal: Fever and lethargy
    • Early: Severe genital pain, edema, erythema
    • Progressive: Skin darkening, crepitus from gas-forming organisms
    • Gangrene: Purulent discharge, necrotic tissue, systemic toxicity
  • Management is aggressive and involves:
    • Immediate resuscitation with fluids
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (to cover both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria)
    • Urgent surgical debridement of necrotic tissue
    • Urinary/fecal diversion if required to prevent contamination
    • Repeated wound evaluation, VAC dressings, and later skin grafting for reconstruction

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Torsion of the testis (Option A): This presents as sudden, severe scrotal pain with rapid swelling and absent cremasteric reflex. It leads to ischemia and gangrene of the testis if untreated but does not present with soft tissue necrosis and foul-smelling discharge.

Acute epididymo-orchitis (Option B): Typically caused by bacterial infections (eg, E. coli, Chlamydia, Gonorrhea), leading to painful, tender scrotal swelling with fever and dysuria. It is not associated with necrosis or crepitus.

Scrotal carcinoma (Option C): Usually presents as a painless, indurated mass or ulcer with everted edges and an indurated base. It is a chronic, slow-growing lesion and not an acute necrotizing infection like Fournier's gangrene.

Key Takeaway:

Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive necrotizing infection of the perineum and genitalia caused by mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. It requires urgent surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics, as delay in management significantly increases mortality.

questions.text: A patient presents with prostate carcinoma, which has now spread to the vertebra. What is the route of spread to the lumbar vertebra?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the vertebra most commonly occurs through Batson's plexus, also known as the vertebral venous plexus.
  • This venous network is valveless, which allows retrograde flow of blood from the pelvic venous system to the spinal venous system.
  • This retrograde pathway facilitates the direct hematogenous spread of malignant cells from the prostate to the lumbar vertebrae, explaining the frequent skeletal metastases in advanced prostate cancer.

Routes of Spread in Prostate Carcinoma:

  • Haematogenous spread (most common): Via Batson's plexus → skeletal metastases (pelvic bones, lumbar vertebrae).
  • Local spread: To bladder, seminal vesicles, and rectum.
  • Lymphatic spread: To pelvic and para-aortic nodes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Transcoelomic spread (Option B): Refers to tumor dissemination across peritoneal surfaces (e.g., ovarian carcinoma), not typical of prostate carcinoma metastasis.

Inferior vesical vein (Option C): Drains the prostate into the internal iliac vein but does not provide a direct channel to the vertebral venous system.

Internal iliac vein (Option D): Drains pelvic organs, including the prostate, but is not the route responsible for vertebral metastasis.

Key Takeaway:

The characteristic spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae occurs through Batson's plexus, a valveless venous network that allows retrograde flow and facilitates skeletal metastases.

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A baby playing unsupervised was brought with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the last few hours. The x-ray image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child's presentation with acute dysphagia and X-ray showing a round opacity in the coronal plane on PA view is classic for a foreign body in the esophagus.
  • Objects like coins, button batteries, or bottle caps usually lodge in the esophagus and appear circular on frontal X-ray.
  • This correlates with the child's difficulty swallowing and confirms the diagnosis.

Management of Ingested Foreign Bodies:

Emergency (Immediate endoscopic removal):

  • Esophageal obstruction (child cannot swallow saliva).
  • Button/disk batteries in the esophagus.
  • Sharp or pointed objects.

Urgent (Within 12-24 hours):

  • Coins and blunt objects in the esophagus.
  • Incomplete obstruction.
  • Multiple magnets or magnets + ferromagnetic object.

Non-Urgent (Observation possible):

  • Blunt objects already in the stomach (<2.5 cm) that are expected to pass spontaneously.
  • Asymptomatic disc battery in the stomach (can wait up to 48 hrs).
  • Blunt objects that fail to progress beyond the stomach within 3-4 weeks.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Foreign body in the trachea (Option A): Causes stridor, wheezing, and respiratory distress. Aligns in the sagittal plane and appears round on lateral view, not PA.

Artifact (Option C): Caused by external items such as clips or clothing. It would not correlate with acute dysphagia or appear lodged in the esophagus.

Soft tissue calcification in the neck (Option D): Can be seen in lymph nodes or vessels but does not mimic a discrete foreign body and is not associated with sudden swallowing difficulty.

Key Takeaway

  • Esophageal foreign body: Appears round on PA view (coronal plane), presents with dysphagia.
  • Tracheal foreign body: Appears round on lateral view (sagittal plane), presents with respiratory symptoms.
  • Management urgency depends on type of object and degree of obstruction.

questions.text: A male patient presents with impotence and absent femoral pulse. Pain in the gluteal region is observed. At which level has pathology occurred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The triad of impotence, gluteal claudication, and absent femoral pulses is classical for Leriche's syndrome, which occurs due to occlusion at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • Pathology at this level compromises blood flow to the lower limbs and pelvic organs, explaining the combination of symptoms.
  • Gluteal pain occurs due to ischemia in the buttock muscles, impotence results from impaired pelvic circulation, and absent femoral pulses reflect poor distal flow.

Leriche's Syndrome (Aortoiliac Occlusion):

  • Clinical triad: Claudication (especially buttock/thigh), impotence, absent femoral pulses.
  • Pathophysiology: Progressive atherosclerotic disease at the bifurcation of the aorta into the common iliac arteries.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical exam showing absent femoral pulses.
    • Doppler and duplex ultrasonography.
    • CT/MR angiography for localization and severity.
  • Treatment:
    • Lifestyle modification and antiplatelet therapy for mild disease.
    • Endovascular stenting or aortobifemoral bypass graft for severe occlusion.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Bilateral popliteal arteries (Option A): Occlusion here causes calf and foot ischemia with absent pedal pulses, but femoral pulses remain palpable, and impotence is not a feature.

Bilateral internal iliac arteries (Option B): This could explain impotence and buttock pain due to reduced pelvic and gluteal blood flow, but femoral pulses would still be present since flow through the external iliac and femoral arteries is intact.

Bilateral femoral arteries (Option D): This causes calf claudication and absent distal pulses, but gluteal pain and impotence are not explained, as pelvic circulation is unaffected.

Key Takeaway:

The combination of impotence, gluteal pain, and absent femoral pulses is pathognomonic for Leriche's syndrome due to aortoiliac bifurcation occlusion, making this the correct site of pathology.

Reference:

NIH Link.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with known gallstones presents with acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, accompanied by vomiting. Laboratory tests confirm acute pancreatitis. Which on admission finding is a component of the updated Ranson criteria for gallstone-induced acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
• The Ranson criteria are a set of clinical and biochemical parameters used to predict severity and mortality risk in acute pancreatitis.
  • They include parameters at admission and at 48 hours.
  • For gallstone-induced pancreatitis, the admission criteria include AST >250 IU/L, which reflects hepatocellular injury and biliary obstruction, common in this etiology.

Ranson Criteria

A score ≥3 indicates severe pancreatitis.

Why Ranson Criteria fit this condition-

  • Condition: Acute gallstone-induced pancreatitis.
  • Gallstones obstruct the ampulla → bile reflux into the pancreatic duct → premature activation of enzymes → local and systemic inflammation.
  • Biliary obstruction also injures hepatocytes, raising AST and bilirubin.
  • Ranson criteria quantify both initial injury and ongoing systemic effects to estimate prognosis and guide care.

Age >55 years (Option A): This threshold applies to non-gallstone (alcohol-related) pancreatitis. In gallstone-induced pancreatitis, the correct age cutoff is >70 years, making this incorrect.

Serum calcium >8 mg/dL (Option C): High calcium is normal. In pancreatitis, low calcium (<8 mg/dL) at 48 hours (due to fat necrosis and saponification) predicts severity. A value >8 mg/dL is not part of the criteria.

Blood glucose >200 mg/dL (Option D): The correct admission threshold for gallstone-induced pancreatitis is >220 mg/dL. A value >200 mg/dL applies to non-gallstone pancreatitis, so this is incorrect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man from a non-western country presents with recurrent episodes of cholangitis. Imaging reveals soft, friable, laminated stones located in the common bile duct. Which type of stones is most likely responsible for his primary choledocholithiasis?
questions.solution:
• Brown pigment stones are typically found in the bile ducts (choledocholithiasis) rather than the gallbladder.
  • They are associated with chronic biliary infections (e.g., bacterial or parasitic) which lead to the deconjugation of bilirubin and the formation of soft, friable, brown-colored stones.
  • In the given scenario, the stones are soft, laminated, located in the ducts, consistent with brown pigment stones.
  • Brown pigment stones are formed in the presence of infection which hydrolyzes conjugated bilirubin.
  • Their location in bile ducts and soft, friable nature differentiates them from cholesterol or black pigment stones.

Cholesterol stones (Option A): Typically occur in the gallbladder, seen in Western countries, hard and crystalline, not usually associated with infection or ducts.

Black pigment stones (Option B): Occur in the gallbladder in non-western countries, associated with hemolysis or ileal disease, hard, brittle, and radio-opaque, not commonly found in ducts.

Mixed stones (Option D): These have overlapping features but are not specifically associated with ductal location or infection. Not the best answer here.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man diagnosed with gastric carcinoma is found to have a tumor that invades the muscularis propria, with two regional lymph nodes positive for metastasis, and no distant metastasis. Based on the TNM staging principles adapted from gastric carcinoma staging (shown in the table below), what is the correct stage?
questions.solution:
• According to the TNM classification:
    • T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria.
    • N1: Metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes.
    • M0: No distant metastasis.
  • In this case, the tumor invades muscularis propria (T2), two regional lymph nodes are positive (N1), and no distant metastases (M0).
  • Therefore, the correct stage is T2N1M0.

T3N2M0 (Option A): Here T3 means tumor has gone beyond muscularis propria into subserosal tissue- not applicable here (only muscularis propria). N2 implies 3-6 nodes, but only 2 nodes are involved. Therefore, incorrect.

T2N2M0 (Option C): T2 is correct, but N2 implies 3-6 nodes- here only 2 nodes are involved. Therefore, incorrect.

T3N1M0 (Option D): T3 is incorrect because there is no penetration beyond muscularis propria. Therefore, incorrect.

choices.text: Age of the patient influences the risk of malignant transformation.
Size of the lesion is an important prognostic factor and affects staging.
Grade of dysplasia predicts malignant potential.
Posterior aspect of the tongue is considered a low-risk site for malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male smoker presents with an ulcerative lesion on the lateral border of the tongue. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity. Examination reveals a 4 cm single ipsilateral lymph node fixed to skin with adjacent structure infiltration (clinically ENE-positive). Regarding factors that affect prognosis or malignant transformation, which among the following statements is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
• The posterior aspect of the tongue (base of tongue) is actually considered a high-risk site for malignant transformation.
  • This area has rich lymphatic drainage and tumors in this location tend to present late, with a higher chance of nodal and distant metastases.
  • Hence, the statement claiming it is a low-risk site is incorrect, making it the correct answer for this question.

Oral Cavity Cancer: Risk Factors and Prognostic Indicators


Age of the patient influences the risk of malignant transformation. (Option A): Older age correlates with a higher risk of developing oral cavity cancers due to cumulative exposure to carcinogens and reduced DNA repair mechanisms. Hence, this is correct.

Size of the lesion is an important prognostic factor and affects staging. (Option B): Larger lesions are associated with higher T stages and worse outcomes, as per TNM criteria. Hence, this is correct.

Grade of dysplasia predicts malignant potential. (Option C): High-grade dysplasia (severe dysplasia or carcinoma in situ) is more likely to transform into invasive cancer. Hence, this is correct.

Reference:https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6528815/

choices.text: Left anterior descending artery- Left main coronary artery disease
Left posterior descending artery- Poor LV function with viable myocardium
Circumflex artery- Ongoing ischemia with NSTEMI unresponsive to medical therapy
Right marginal branch- Survivors of sudden cardiac death with ischemia-mediated VT

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with severe coronary artery disease and left main coronary artery stenosis is scheduled for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. He also has disabling angina despite maximal medical therapy. Which of the following is the most commonly bypassed artery during CABG in such patients, and which clinical indication correctly justifies CABG in this case?
questions.solution:
• The left anterior descending (LAD) artery is the most commonly bypassed artery during CABG. It supplies a large portion of the left ventricle and is most frequently involved in critical stenoses.
  • One of the class I indications for CABG, as per the ACC/AHA guidelines is left main coronary artery disease, which is present in this patient.
  • Disabling angina despite optimal medical therapy also supports the decision for CABG.

2. Indications for CABG (ACC/AHA guidelines):

Class I Indications:

  • Left main coronary artery disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD involvement
  • Two-vessel disease with proximal LAD involvement
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT

Other indications:

  • Disabling angina refractory to medical therapy
  • Ongoing ischemia with NSTEMI unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function with viable myocardium amenable to revascularization

Left posterior descending artery- Poor LV function with viable myocardium (Option B): Left posterior descending is less commonly bypassed, and while poor LV function with viable myocardium is an indication for CABG, it is not the most common scenario. Therefore, incorrect.

Circumflex artery- Ongoing ischemia with NSTEMI unresponsive to medical therapy (Option C): The circumflex artery is not the most commonly bypassed, and although ongoing ischemia is a valid indication, it does not match the most common artery. Therefore, incorrect.

Right marginal branch- Survivors of sudden cardiac death with ischemia-mediated VT (Option D): Right marginal branch is rarely bypassed, and while sudden cardiac death with ischemia-mediated VT is an indication, it does not involve the most commonly bypassed artery. Therefore, incorrect.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman undergoes screening mammography. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed, oval, non-calcified lesion with smooth margins. The radiologist assesses it as unlikely to be malignant but not definitively benign, recommending short-interval follow-up mammograms every 6 months for 2 years.
According to the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS), which of the following categories correctly applies?
questions.solution:
• The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is a structured reporting tool used in mammography, ultrasound, and MRI to classify breast findings based on their likelihood of malignancy and to guide clinical management.
  • A probably benign finding corresponds to BI-RADS 3:
  • Estimated risk of malignancy: >0% but ≤2%
  • Management: 6-month follow-up mammograms for 2 years to confirm stability.
  • Such findings are not definitively benign but have a very low chance of cancer and do not initially warrant biopsy.

BI-RADS 1- Negative (Option A): This applies when there is no abnormal finding at all, requiring only routine screening. Incorrect because a lesion was detected.

BI-RADS 2- Benign finding (Option B): This is used when the lesion is definitively benign (e.g., a simple cyst or fat necrosis), requiring only routine screening. Incorrect here as the lesion is not definitively benign.

BI-RADS 4- Suspicious abnormality (Option D): This applies when the finding has a higher probability of malignancy (>2% to <95%), where biopsy is recommended. Not correct here because the risk is ≤2%, and immediate biopsy is not warranted.

choices.text: Only in cases of ongoing internal bleeding
Within 3 hours of trauma with signs of significant haemorrhage
Only if the patient requires transfusion
In cases of isolated head injury without haemorrhage

questions.text: A 28 year old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with significant blood loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate indication for administering tranexamic acid?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid, an antifibrinolytic, stabilises clots by inhibiting fibrinolysis and is most effective when given within 3 hours of trauma in patients with significant haemorrhage (e.g., systolic BP <110 mmHg, pulse >110/min).

Tranexamic Acid in Trauma:

Indications:

  • Early Administration: Most effective when given within 3 hours of trauma in patients with significant bleeding.
  • Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have significant haemorrhage, including those with a systolic blood pressure of <110 mmHg or a pulse of over 110 per minute.
  • It needs to be administered as early as possible and ideally within the first hour from injury; the first dose should not be administered more than 3 hours from injury.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Antifibrinolytic: Inhibits the breakdown of fibrin clots, helping to stabilise formed clots and reduce bleeding.

Clinical Evidence:

  • CRASH2 Trial: Demonstrated a reduction in mortality when tranexamic acid was administered early in trauma patients.

Contraindications:

  • Isolated Head Injury: Not typically recommended unless there is associated haemorrhage.
  • Late Administration: Less effective if given beyond 3 hours after injury.

Complications:

  • Thrombosis: Though rare, there is a theoretical risk of thrombotic complications with antifibrinolytic therapy.

Explanations of other options:

Only in cases of ongoing internal bleeding (Option A): Tranexamic acid is indicated for any significant haemorrhage, not just internal bleeding, and timing (within 3 hours) is critical.

Only if the patient requires transfusion (Option C): Tranexamic acid should be given to prevent or control significant bleeding, regardless of transfusion need, to reduce mortality.

In cases of isolated head injury without haemorrhage (Option D): Tranexamic acid is not indicated for isolated head injury without evidence of significant bleeding, as its benefit is in haemorrhage control.

Key Takeaways:

Tranexamic acid is most effective when given within 3 hours of trauma in patients with significant haemorrhage, per CRASH-2 trial evidence.

questions.text: A 45 year old female is found unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. To open her airway, what is the most appropriate manoeuvre to use if there is no suspicion of a cervical spine injury?
questions.solution:
The head tilt, chin lift manoeuvre is the first-line technique to open the airway in an unconscious patient without suspected cervical spine injury. It is contraindicated in suspected cervical spine injury, where the jaw thrust manoeuvre is preferred.

Head Tilt, Chin Lift Manoeuvre:

Purpose:

  • Head Tilt, Chin Lift: A technique used to open the airway in an unconscious patientby preventing the tongue from obstructing the airway.

Indications:

  • Unconscious Patients: Particularly those without a suspected cervical spine injury.
  • Airway Obstruction: Due to the tongue falling back against the pharynx, common in unconscious patients.

Technique:

  • Head Tilt:Place one hand on the patient's forehead and gently tilt the head back.
  • Chin Lift: Use the fingertips of your other hand to lift the chin upwards and forwards.

Contraindications:

  • Suspected Cervical Spine Injury: In such cases, the jaw thrustmanoeuvre should be used instead, as it does not involve movement of the cervical spine.

Complications:

  • Exacerbation of Cervical Spine Injury
  • Inadequate Airway Opening

Explanation of other options:

Jaw thrust manoeuvre (Option A) is used when cervical spine injury is suspected, as it opens the airway without moving the neck.

Nasopharyngeal airway insertion (Option B) is an adjunct device, not the initial manoeuvre, used when airway obstruction persists.

Oropharyngeal airway insertion (Option D) is an adjunct device, not the first-line manoeuvre, and is used in unconscious patients to maintain airway patency.

Key Takeaway:

The head tilt, chin lift manoeuvre is the preferred method for opening the airway in unconscious patients without suspected cervical spine injury.

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with a groin mass below the inguinal ligament that becomes more prominent with standing. You suspect a femoral hernia. Which structure forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal?
questions.solution:
The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal.

Femoral Canal

  • Location: The femoral canal lies medial to the femoral vein within the femoral sheath.
  • Contents: The canal contains lymphatic vessels, a lymph node (Cloquet's node), and loose connective tissue.
  • Function: It allows the femoral vein to expand and provides a pathway for lymphatic drainage from the lower limb.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior: Inguinal ligament
    • Posterior: Pectineal ligament
    • Medial: Lacunar ligament
    • Lateral: Femoral vein

Explanation of Options:

Femoral vein (Option A):The femoral vein is located lateral to the femoral canal.

Inguinal ligament (Option B):The inguinal ligament forms the superior boundary of the femoral canal.

Pectineal ligament (Option D): The pectineal ligament forms the posterior boundary of the femoral canal.

Key points:

The femoral canal is the site of femoral hernias, more common in women and prone to incarceration due to its narrow structure.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and flank pain. Imaging shows a cystic dilation at the distal end of the ureter inside the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter at the ureterovesical junction, often causing obstruction, hydronephrosis, and recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). It appears as a "cobra head" on imaging (e.g., intravenous urogram) and is common in ectopic or duplex ureters.

Ureterocele:

  • Cystic dilation of the distal ureter, often at the ureterovesical junction. It can cause obstruction, leading to hydronephrosis and recurrent infections.
  • Types:
    • Simple (orthotopic) and ectopic.
    • Ectopic ureteroceles are more common in duplex systems and are associated with significant clinical symptoms.
  • Symptoms:
    • Recurrent UTIs, flank pain, hematuria, or asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound or cystoscopy may show a ballooning of the distal ureter within the bladder.
    • When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice. The classic feature of a ureterocele on an intravenous urogram (IVU) is the 'cobra head'
  • Management:
    • The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with reimplantation of the ureter.
    • Endoscopic incision of a ureterocele is the preferred treatment method for simple ureteroceles in infants and small children, but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux.
    • A non-functioning kidney may need nephrectomy.

Explanations of other options:

Vesicoureteral reflux (Option A) involves retrograde urine flow from the bladder to the ureter, causing UTIs but not a cystic dilation within the bladder.

Urethral diverticulum (Option C) is a sac-like outpouching of the urethra, presenting with dysuria or dribbling, not ureteral dilation or flank pain.

Bladder cystitis (Option D): Cystitis causes bladder inflammation and symptoms like dysuria and frequency, not ureteral cystic dilation or flank pain.

Key Takeaway:

Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter, causing UTIs and flank pain, often seen on imaging as a "cobra head."

questions.text: A 50 year old male is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is hypotensive, bradycardic, and has warm extremities. His physical exam reveals flaccid paralysis below the level of T6. What type of shock is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock, a type of distributive shock, results from loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury above T6. It presents with hypotension, bradycardia (due to unopposed parasympathetic activity), and warm, dry skin (due to vasodilation).

Spinal Shock vs. Neurogenic Shock:

Explanation of other options:

Hypovolemic shock (Option A): This presents with hypotension, tachycardia, and cool, clammy skin due to blood loss, not bradycardia or warm extremities.

Cardiogenic shock (Option B): This involves hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of heart failure (e.g., pulmonary oedema), not flaccid paralysis or bradycardia.

Spinal shock (Option C): This refers to a temporary loss of neurological function (motor, sensory, reflexes) below the injury level, not directly causing hemodynamic instability like neurogenic shock.

Key Takeaway: Neurogenic shock, caused by spinal cord injury above T6, leads to hypotension, bradycardia, and warm extremities due to loss of sympathetic tone.

choices.text: A retrosternal goiter is typically removed via a thoracotomy.
All retrosternal goiters require a sternotomy for removal.
Over 95% of retrosternal goitres can be removed transcervically.
Surgery should always be performed in elderly patients, regardless of symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia and mild shortness of breath. Imaging reveals a large retrosternal goiter extending into the superior mediastinum. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the management of retrosternal goitre?
questions.solution:
Retrosternal goitres, extending into the mediastinum, often cause symptoms like dysphagia or dyspnea due to compression. Over 95% can be removed via a transcervical approach, avoiding invasive procedures like sternotomy, which is reserved for large, fixed, or malignant goitres.

Retrosternal Goitre:

  • It is a multinodular thyroid gland that grows into the mediastinum, potentially causing compression of surrounding structures.
  • Symptoms:Most patients are asymptomatic, but larger goitres can cause dysphagia, airway compression, and tracheal deviation.
  • Indications for Surgery:
    • Significant airway compression.
    • Symptomatic patients (dysphagia, dyspnea).
    • Young patients are likely to develop symptoms.
  • Surgical Approach:
    • TranscervicalApproach: Over 95% of retrosternal goitres can be removed transcervically.
    • Sternotomy: Required in <5% of cases, particularly for large or fixed goitres, or when malignant disease is suspected.
  • Preoperative Imaging: Cross-sectional imaging (CT) is crucial for assessing the extent of the goitre and planning the surgical approach.

Explanations of other options:

A retrosternal goitre is typically removed via a thoracotomy (Option A): Thoracotomy is rarely used; the transcervical approach is standard for most retrosternal goitres.

All retrosternal goitres require a sternotomy for removal (Option B): Sternotomy is needed in <5% of cases, typically for large or malignant goitres, not all cases.

Surgery should always be performed in elderly patients, regardless of symptoms (Option D): Asymptomatic elderly patients are often managed with observation, as surgery carries risks in this population.

Key Points:

Over 95% of retrosternal goitres are removed transcervically, with sternotomy reserved for select cases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presented with a small, pearly nodule measuring 0.3 cm on the left nasolabial fold, with occasional bleeding. The lesion was excised, and histopathological examination was performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 0.3 cm nodule on the left nasolabial fold is most likely to represent a Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC), especially given the location on the nasolabial fold, which is a common site for BCC.

Melanoma (Option B) is a malignant tumor from melanocytes, typically appearing as a dark, irregular lesion-not a small, pearly nodule like in this case.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option C) presents as a scaly or ulcerated nodule and has a higher risk of metastasis, unlike the slow-growing, pearly BCC.

Nevus (Option D) is a benign, well-circumscribed pigmented lesion, usually flat or slightly raised, and not pearly or firm like basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: On postoperative day 3, how does a skin graft primarily receive its nutrition?
questions.solution:
On day 3 post-grafting, the graft depends primarily on Imbibition for its nutrition.

  • It is the process by which the graft absorbs nutrients and oxygen directly from the surrounding tissue through diffusion.
  • Occurs within the first 72 hours post-transplantation.

Skin graft Take:

The process of skin graft healing is called "Skin graft Take." The phases ofgraft takeinvolve a series of 3 steps critical for the successful integration of a graft into the recipient site. These phases are:

  • Serum Imbibition (Plasmatic Circulation): In the first 48 hours, the graft is sustained by plasma exudate from the capillaries in the host bed. (Option A)
  • Inosculation, where graft and host vessels form direct connections (complete in 4-5 days). (Option B ruled out)
  • Neovascularization, where new blood vessels grow from the recipient site into the graft. It starts after imbibition and inosculation, around 7 to 14 days post-grafting. (Option C ruled out)

Organisation: This phase begins immediately after grafting, with a fibrin layer forming at the graft-bed interface to stabilise the graft. By day 7, this layer is replaced by fibroblasts, and by days 10 to 14, the graft is typically well-adhered to the underlying bed.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551561/

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with severe vomiting of blood. Ultrasound reveals a distended portal vein and a hyperechoic liver. He has been started on pantoprazole. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with severe hematemesis, distended portal vein, and hypoechoic liver suggests Upper GI (gastrointestinal) Bleeding, requiring immediate stabilisation with intravenous fluids with electrolyte replacement.

Management:

  • PPI/Tranexamic acid/Octreotide administration.
  • IV fluids and electrolyte replacement to stabilise the patient. (Option C)
  • Endoscopic variceal ligation is performed, followed by endoscopic sclerotherapy.(Option D ruled out)

Following is the algorithm used for management:

Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics (Option A): Antibiotics are initiated only after the bleeding has been controlled.

Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis (Option B): Liver biopsy is not necessary in the initial management of upper GI bleed.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of recurrent diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and foul-smelling stools. Colonoscopy reveals characteristic mucosal changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of recurrent diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and foul-smelling stools, along with colonoscopy revealing raised, yellowish-white plaques or pseudomembranes on the mucosal surface, indicates Pseudomembranous Colitis.

FAP (Option B): An inherited condition with numerous colonic polyps, typically without recurrent diarrhea or foul-smelling stools. Colonoscopy shows multiple polyps, not pseudomembranes.

Ulcerative colitis (Option C): Causes abdominal pain and diarrhea, but colonoscopy reveals continuous mucosal ulceration, not pseudomembranes.

Acute gastritis (Option D): Affects the stomach, presenting with upper abdominal pain and nausea. It doesn't cause diarrhea, and colonoscopy isn't used for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with new-onset confusion. He is on antihypertensives and aspirin after a recent myocardial infarction. He reports a minor fall from a chair about three weeks ago. Neurological examination is unremarkable. Based on the imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario of confusion, recent MI, antihypertensive and aspirin use, a minor fall, and a crescent-shaped, hyperdense, or isodense lesion on CT points to a Subdural Hematoma (SDH), typically caused by bridging vein rupture, often following trauma or in elderly individuals.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (Option C): Shows diffuse hyperdensity in the subarachnoid spaces on CT, often around sulci and ventricles, usually caused by ruptured aneurysms or AV malformations.

Contusion (Option D): Appears as localized mixed-density hemorrhages within brain tissue with surrounding edema on CT, typically focal rather than diffuse or crescent-shaped.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging, irregular breast lump measuring 5 x 6 cm. Histopathology reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes a 5 x 6 cm irregular mass, and histopathological examination reveals whorled stroma and leaf-like structures, leading to a diagnosis of Phyllodes Tumor (also referred to as Phylloid Tumor or Cystosarcoma Phyllodes).

Fibroadenoma (Option B): A benign, well-circumscribed, mobile mass common in younger women, lacking the stromal overgrowth and irregularity seen in phyllodes tumors.

Mastitis (Option C): Breast infection with pain, redness, and swelling-not a discrete mass; histology shows inflammation, not tumor features.

Grade 2 breast tumour (Option D), such as invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC), exhibits moderate cellular abnormalities, increased mitotic activity, and disorganised growth, replacing normal breast tissue with irregular nests of cancerous cells. In contrast to phylloid tumours, IDC does not have a characteristic leaf-like pattern or well-formed stroma.

questions.text: Mrs Kamala operated for Hysterectomy by open method 4 days back presents with wound shown below. Which of the following is the grade as per Southampton Grading:
questions.solution:
In a simplified form ( Mnemonic- EISPA*)

  • Grade 1- Erythema
  • Grade 2- Induration
  • Grade 3- Serous discharge
  • Grade 4- Pus
  • Grade 5- Anatomical break down as shown in image

Below is the extensive table from Bailey and Love

questions.text: An old bedridden patient brought to clinic with complaints of pain and blackish discolouration of skin over occiput. Regarding decubitus ulcer true are all except
questions.solution:
• These can be defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. Less preferable terms are bed sores, pressure ulcers and decubitus ulcers.
  • They should be regarded as preventable but occur in approximately 5% of all hospitalised patients.
  • There is a higher incidence in paraplegic patients, in the elderly and in the severely ill patient.

Pressure sore frequency in descending order

  • Ischium
  • Greater trochanter
  • Sacrum
  • Heel
  • Malleolus (lateral then medial)
  • Occiput

questions.text: Identify the name of the incision '10' in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Incision names:

  1. Midline
  2. Kocher's subcostal for Cholecystectomy
  3. Thoraco abdominal
  4. Rectus split
  5. Paramedian
  6. Transverse ( used in Paediatric surgery)
  7. Mc burney's
  8. Inguinal
  9. Pfannensteil
  10. McEvedy- Used in obstructed Femoral hernia
  11. Not a skin incision- its muscle cutting Rutherford Morrison Incision

questions.text: Mr Bhatia is having a cancer in rectum and the surgeon is deciding to resect the tumor by laparoscopic method. After resection he decides to do anastomosis by using this instrument. What will be the technique of anastomosis usually done by this instrument?
questions.solution:
End-to-end anastomoses.

  • Circular stapling devices allow tubes to be joined together, and such instruments are in common use in the oesophagus and low rectum.
  • The detached stapling head/anvil is introduced into one end of the bowel, usually being secured within it by means of a purse-string suture.
  • The body of the device is then inserted into the other end of the bowel, either via the rectum for
  • a low rectal anastomosis, or via an enterotomy for an oesophago-jejunostomy, and the shaft is either extended through a small opening in the bowel wall or secured by a further purse-string suture.
  • The head/anvil is reattached to the shaft and the two ends approximated.
  • Once the device is fully closed, as indicated by the green indicator in the window, the device is fired, and, after unwinding, the stapler is gently withdrawn.
  • It is important to assess the integrity of the anastomosis by examining the 'doughnuts' of tissue excised for completeness.
  • It is essential that no extraneous tissue is allowed to become interposed between the two bowel walls on closing the stapler.

questions.text: Mr Ramu, 40 years male had head injury and presented with pupillary abnormalities and hemiplegia. Which of the following herniation is associated with such abnormalities from the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Brain herniation.

1- Herniation of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri is termed subfalcine herniation

2- Midline shift is evident.

3- Uncal herniation: the temporal lobe is herniating over the tentorium cerebelli where it can compress the third nerve.

4- Central brain stem herniation and

5- Cerebellar tonsillar herniation result in brainstem compromise, manifesting as Cushing's triad.

questions.text: A patient 50 years old with a swelling in front of ear comes with pain in the swelling and mild deviation of mouth to opposite side noted on examination. You noted the swelling is hard in consistency and patient has a node in the neck hard and mobile in Level 2. What is the most probable diagnosis from this clinical scenario:
questions.solution:
Features suggestive of malignant tumors:

  • Facial nerve weakness
  • Sudden rapid enlargement of gland
  • Ulceration and induration on skin
  • Node enlargement in Cervical group.
